Y'all are overthinking this. The MAN is trying to make you miserable, you either succumb or you don't. That's the extent of the message. You can word it fancier, more flowery but that's it.

Nothing the im14andthisisdeep community hasn't gone over a million times.

Now get this weak shit out of my hentai.

P.S. All those people comapring this to Ito, I bite my thumb at thee.

[cont] When the wawawa girl puts the costume back on, she flees from the idea of gender, becomes "pure" again and breaks away from what a "girl" is meant to be. Looking at it that way might explain the last page, which is the first time the girls are actually referred to as "girls/female" and not "children" or "kids" or "person" etc. 

Still have no idea what the "I really don't wanna go to school tomorrow" part is supposed to mean though.

It's really interesting that everyone seems to think something different of this. I personally thought it was a commentary on how the domestication of an animal breaks them, one guy on panda thinks it's a commentary on the schooling system and how it crushes individuality, another guy thinks it's a developed society forcing their views on a primitive one, and there's good ideas here too.
I also found a review on this story when I was trying to look up the writer (雨雲ツナミ): http://makaronisan.hatenablog.com/entry/20090427/1240749651
And to sum up kinda quickly this dude thinks the forest they were in was artificial and being controlled by the people at the school. He says the girls in the forest are pure because they have no idea what sex/gender is, and that when they're taken away they're given a "gender" (symbolized as a uniform) by the adults. The other weird girls have already been made into "what a girl is supposed to be" and are like empty shells.
World is gotta burn for the sake of humanity

@FirekeeperIsMyGoddess deserve an award for explaining everything (and being best wafiu)
@EvilRyo, I've thought of that at first but the last panel kinda contradicted my idea a little bit, nice analysis though, short but meaningful!

Man, what a depressing trip. 
I suppose you can find parallels on the domestication of wild animals since it shows that image of a sheep being sheared when they take their kigurumi. 
Also the loss of innocence like firekeeper says. 
Last panel could be referring to how she is adapting by herself but could also mean she's rebelling by burning everyone's shoes.

I forgot to mention the last panel (silly me). The part where the clinic doctor said, "It's not like there are many ways a girl can live, anyway.", was an explanation that the world they were in is very restrictive, like a dystopian reality built on top of our world. It can also be described in a different way. If the author meant that the last part was more of an overlook of our world, then it could mean something different. The author could also say that us humans don't really have that much of a choice: one or zero, yes or no, win or lose. These actions have numerous consequences that's why they're very restraining. Being confined to a choice of a lifetime is reality. People often suffer fates they didn't dream of and the manga really describes that pretty well. Both suffer the same fates but only one can call herself "happy" (whatever that word means). Thanks for reading!

After the act, the clinic's doctor allowed them to return back to their old nature, to wear the animal costumes back, removing their status as student. One of the girls, the blonde, decided to wear the costume. The other girl, the pony tailed, didn't join her, the look in her face seems sad, confused and even afraid. The next day started, the one that didn't wear the costume, suffered a gruesome fate, while the other that accepted the costume bore freedom for herself, not being bound to rules and she was able to smile once more. What I think the author was trying to get by was that we must not be afraid of choosing who we want to be. The blonde girl was happy because she was given the chance to be happy and accepted it. While the pony tailed girl was afraid to escape the dark reality, while the chance was already laid out before her. I honestly loved the story, I feel like there should be more world building, it would certainly be an interesting world. I'm wishing for a sequel.

A lot would probably be confused after reading the last page, I'll try to explain it as best as I could to you guys. Note that I'm one of the people that have no idea about this and has only read it, I'm analyzing this story with my own experience and judgement. The children wearing animal costumes have never learned anything, they use their natural tendencies and instincts to get around and survive. We also learn that they have outstanding health, from this I can symbolize that these children are a representation of purity and clarity. Teachers from a school kidnapped them and were forced to take a new role, they were no longer mindless children, they are now students. The teachers replaced their animal costumes to student's uniforms, destroying their nature. These new roles don't fit for them, they have never learned anything, resulting in isolation and reclusion because they couldn't fit in. These teachers punished these girls for not fitting in, by violating their bodies...
